I told you (Ladies) if your tender hearts</br>Admit attention, while my tongue imparts</br>Such heavie newes, how young Eramio came</br>With yearly incense, to the hallow'd fame</br>Of the Alphaean worship, and how fate</br>Abridg'd his life with nights eternall date.</br>I told you also (leaving her asleep)</br>How Sepha's eyes ore-charg'd with tears did weep,</br>And as she swounded how her curious hands</br>Did give the earth a print, which print still stands,</br>To keep her fame alive, but what it was,</br>Through too much grief my tongue did overpass,</br>As fit'st, it seems, to be inserted here,</br>That as my heavy story doth draw neer</br>Towards her end, so her immortall praise,</br>Rap't in her sweet Encomions may raise</br>Conjugall tears from each distilling eye,</br>Whose praise and fame shall them accompany</br>With her harmonious voice, I mean the love</br>Her soul will powr upon them from above.</br>And that her eyes may make all sighs the fairer,</br>Her soul will smile to see the love they bare her.</br>The spices which Eramio had strew'd</br>About the altar, her wet eyes bedew'd</br>With sorrowing tears, which daily they did cast</br>Upon the same, and made thereof a paste;</br>Like those congealed clouds which some have given</br>A glorious title, call'd the walls of Heaven.</br>So Sepha falling, fell upon the same,</br>From whose fair hand that fair impression came,</br>By some swift Savo call'd, for many say</br>From thence Campanian Savo took her way,</br>And there it is where each Campanian maid,</br>For yearly offerings her vow hath paid</br>With the Medean draughts, t' revive the fame</br>Of Sepha dead; Savo from Sepha came:</br>But that's not all, the print whereof I spake,</br>Though some affirm 'tis, yet 'tis not a Lake.</br>For if the spices which Eramio cast,</br>Dry'd up her tears, and thereof made a paste,</br>How can a Lake ensue?  but this is sure,</br>There was a corner of the altar pure</br>From any blot, on this Eramio laid</br>His Aromatick spices as he praid.</br>This being turn'd into a past by those</br>Distilling eyes (which dying seldome close,)</br>The palm of her fair hand did gently press</br>The yeelding paste, and as she up it reard,</br>Like a triangled heart the print appeard,</br>The fingers standing just upon the heart,</br>Presented Cupids shafts, which he doth dart</br>On simple souls, from whence ensues the bloud,</br>The blood being gon, came that Campanian flood;</br>Thus palm and fingers having shown the love</br>By Cupids net intangled, strait did move</br>T' another form no figure there was seen,</br>While yet they gaze upon't, the place grows green;</br>At this they stare, at this a flower up-starts,</br>Which still presents the form of wounded hearts.</br>This being seen by Nymphs that haunt the Springs,</br>Each took a slip, it to their Mansion brings,</br>Where being set, it's now in every grove,</br>A pretty flower, and call'd the Lady-glove.</br>Now let me tell of Sepha, and her hap</br>That did ensue, while she in Fortunes lap</br>Lies lull'd asleep, (sleep had her sense bereav'd)</br>(And chiefly for the love she had conceiv'd</br>Of her Arcadius) bethinking hard,</br>Either he is of charity debarr'd,</br>Or linkt t' anothers virtue, and surmising</br>Hee's not to be imbrac'd; waking and rising,</br>She found her self by him to be imbrac't,</br>Who, being present at her fall, did haste</br>To hale her breath again; those eyes that wrought</br>Confusion first, now more confusion brought;</br>Having Arcadius kist, she thinks some dream</br>Deludes her wandering sense, in which extream</br>Rapt with conceit of this her present good,</br>Her greedy eyes with ardent wishes woo'd,</br>That Heaven, in which her present hopes remain'd</br>A worlds continuance, and she had obtain'd</br>What she desir'd, had not the winged boy</br>Unbent his bow, with period of their joy.</br>Yet something to her hopes he did admit,</br>To whet the heavy sacrificers wit;</br>While young Arcadius with trembling hand,</br>Felt how the pulse, as if at Deaths command,</br>Sounded a loud Alarm; fair Heav'n said he,</br>In whom all grace and vertues planted be,</br>Why will you suffer that infernall hound?</br>To dare to come, to give this heart this wound?</br>Use that celestiall power, the powerfull Gods</br>Have giv'n, that grief and you may live at odds.</br>I know those eyes, one wink from those fair eyes</br>Have power to banish hence all miseries</br>Are incident to man so rare a gift</br>Did nature find, when onely but this shift</br>T' amaze spectators she for you had left,</br>For know when Nature fram'd you she bereft</br>The world of all perfections, to make</br>You of divine, and Heav'nly good partake,</br>As well as humane, that there might agree</br>In you, of every grace a sympathy.</br>So said, the blushing damsell with delight</br>Of this new friend, did with her eyes requite</br>His too soon ended speech, O Heav'ns she said,</br>That have respect to me unworthy maid,</br>And daigne this good to me so oft desir'd,</br>Direct me so, that e're I have expir'd</br>This perfect bliss, and am depriv'd the same,</br>I may enjoy the knowledg of his name.</br>Grant this (ye Gods) to me, impatient, till</br>I know his name, his Countrey, and his will.</br>Then did she pull her scarf from off her face,</br>And putting by her hair with that sweet grace,</br>That Venus us'd, when to Adonis eyes</br>She did expose her love, Sepha did rise</br>With such sweet looks as cannot be exprest,</br>And said, these favors Sir, and sigh'd the rest.</br>Well, thought Arcadius, something there remains,</br>And tis some weighty cause that it detains,</br>(Grant Heav'n) that as I hope, so it may prove,</br>By her unpollisht sentence to be love.</br>For he in dreams and visions oft had seen</br>A Lady, who for him alone had been</br>Tortur'd a thousand wayes, with blubbred cheeks,</br>She oft had said, receive her love, who seeks</br>No other life, than for thy owne deserts</br>T' enjoy thy presence, and admire thy parts.</br>She being now recover'd sate her down</br>To view Arcadius, whom the Priest did crown</br>With wreaths of Lawrell, which he alwayes wore</br>For the upright affection that he bore.</br>Then to the Altar went he, where he praid,</br>While Sepha overcome with passion, said,</br>So loud that he might hear, were I the Saint</br>To whom he prayes, sure I would hear his plaint.</br>At this Arcadius look't upon her lips,</br>And blest them that they let that message slip;</br>Then with his pure devotion onward goes,</br>          and on the Altar throwes</br>A winged heart, which lately he had got</br>For sacrifice, about the heart was wrote</br>These next insuing lines.

The purest peice of Mans delight,</br>In whom his life, and Love consists,</br>Whose softness keeps from gloomy night,</br>Which nought can peirce, but Amatysts</br>Is here presented on thy Throne.</br>Bedew'd with tears of faithfull vowes,</br>Presenting thee what is thy own,</br>The best to please thy virgin browes,</br>To fan thy face with her cool wings,</br>And fly the faster as she sings.

Which I by chance,</br>The better his sad story to advance,</br>Have Copi'd forth; about the wings there was</br>Some other Lines, which I will not let pass,</br>That (Gentle Ladies) ye may not have cause,</br>Of his devotion to detract th' applause.

Fly swift my thoughts, and through this sacred fire,</br>Mount up to her, let her to me retire,</br>That by those sweet distilling drops above,</br>She may infuse to me religious love,</br>So may I live, and scape the Dart,</br>While her sweet breath saivs up my heart,</br>And flourish like those Flowers it fills</br>With Nectar sweet, which one frown kils,</br>First let Voluptas weep,</br>And Gloria fall asleep,</br>Castalion liquor's free,</br>Medea bitter bee,</br>E're I forsake</br>Thy praise to make,</br>Or yet deny</br>Thy pietie.

These and the like Arcadius presents,</br>Mingled with deep, and choice perfuming sents</br>Of many bitter sighs, he turnd him round,</br>Salutes the Priest, the Altar, and the ground</br>Whereon it stood then to faire Sepha turns,</br>Who while her heart with strange affection burns,</br>Meets him with nimble eyes, he gently bends</br>A Trembling Cringe to Sepha, who attends</br>With her impatient eares that happy houre,</br>When the wish't Sun shall show that gracious flower</br>She loves unknowne, till a sigh doth bewray,</br>As if the prologue for a following play,</br>These next ensuing words, and such they were,</br>They did requite the time she stayd to hear.</br>Harpocrates may clame a vow I made,</br>(Faire Lady) under his beloved shade;</br>When my insipient years too too blame,</br>With rash attempts to Lauralize the fame</br>Of Cupids power, invested that disgrace,</br>Which still should be a shadow to my face.</br>Then, cause one way did lead to both their Towers,</br>He took hir Magick hand, and with whole showers</br>Of tears first washt them, then with a faint kiss,</br>Dri'd them, and walking homeward told her this.

THE STORY OF PHAON AND SAPPHO.</br>In Lesbos famous for the comick layes,</br>That us'd to spring from her o'reflowing praise,</br>Twice famous Sappho dwelt the fairest maid</br>Mitelin had, of whom it once was said</br>Amongst the Gods, a sudden question was,</br>If Sappho, or Thalia did surpass</br>In Lyribliring tunes, it long remaind,</br>Till Mnemosyne the Mother was constrain'd,</br>To say they both from her begetting sprang,</br>And each of th' others warbling Lyra sang.</br>There was a Town in Lesbos, now defac'd,</br>Antissa nam'd, by Neptunes arms imbrac'd;</br>There Sappho had a Tower, in it a grove</br>Bedeck'd with pearls, and strew'd about with love;</br>Leucothean branches overspred the same,</br>And from the shadowes perfect odors came.</br>To dress it most there was a purple bed,</br>All wrought in works, with azure mantles spred,</br>The tables did unspotted carpets hold</br>Of lyrian dyes, the edges fring'd with gold.</br>Along this grove there stealing ran a Spring,</br>Where Sappho tun'd her Muse, for she could sing</br>In golden verse, and teach the best a vain</br>Beyond the musick of their sweetest straine.</br>Here while she sang, a ruddy youth appear'd,</br>Drawn by the sweetness of the voice he heard,</br>Sing on said he (fair Lady) let not me,</br>Too bold, give period to your melody.</br>Nor blame me for my over bold attempt,</br>(Although I yeeld of modesty exempt</br>In doing this) and yet not over bold,</br>For who so hears the voice, and doth behold</br>The lips from whence it comes, would be as sad</br>As I, and trust me Lady if I had</br>But skill to tempt you with so sweet a touch,</br>Assure you, you your selfe would doe as much.</br>She answers not, for why the little God</br>Had touch'd her heart before, and made a rod</br>For one contempt was past, she view'd him hard,</br>Whose serious looks made Phaon half affeard</br>She was displeas'd, about to goe she cryes,</br>Stay gentle Knight, and take with thee the prize,</br>To thee alone assur'd; the boy look'd pale,</br>But strait a ruddy blush did make a veil</br>T' obscure the same; while thus he panting stood,</br>A thousand times he wisht him in the Wood</br>From whence he came, and speaking not a word,</br>Let fall his hat, his javelin and his sword.</br>She being young, and glad of an occasion,</br>Stoopt down to take them up; he with perswasion</br>Of an half shewing love, detains her hand</br>From it, and with his fingers made the band</br>To chain them fast, (now Love had laid his scean)</br>And draw'd the tragick plot, whereon must lean</br>The ground of all his Acts; (great Deity)</br>When thy foreseeing nove-sight can descry</br>Things which will hap, why dost thou train their love</br>With pleasant musick to deceitfull groves?</br>See how the love of some with equall weight,</br>By vertue poiz'd, live free from all deceit,</br>To whom thou help'st with thy beloved darts,</br>And link'st their true inviolable hearts,</br>Why deal'st not so withall?  are some too hard?</br>Or hath inchanted spells their hearts debarr'd</br>From thy keen shafts?  you Powers should be upright</br>Not harmfull Gods yet thou still tak'st delight</br>In bloody ends, why did'st not wink at these?</br>And send thy shafts a thousand other wayes</br>That more deserv'd thy anger?  or if needs</br>Thou would'st be doing, while thy power proceeds</br>In lofty flames one flame requires another.</br>Why did'st thou wound the one, and not the other?</br>For (Lady) so it past between the lovers,</br>That after little pause Sappho discovers</br>Those kindled flames which never can expire,</br>But his contempt adds fuell to her fire.</br>Immodest Girl he said, why art so rude</br>To woo?  when vertuous women should be woo'd,</br>And scarce obtain'd by wooing, O forbeare,</br>Sweet Sappho cry'd, if I do not prepare</br>A just excuse by none to be deny'd,</br>Never let me — so sate her down and cry'd.</br>He mov'd for pity more to see her tears,</br>Than toucht with any loyall love he bears,</br>Sate down by her, while she dispairing, laid</br>Her eyes on his, her hands on his, and said,</br>Ay me, that herbs for love no cure afford,</br>Whose too too jealous actions will accord</br>To nought but semblable desire, that lost,</br>What pain more vile than lovers that are crost</br>With hopeles hopes?  they say'ts a God that works</br>The same, but sure some Devill tis that lurks</br>His opportunity how to destroy,</br>And tear the Soul from her aspiring joy.</br>Now to prevent occasions that may fall,</br>Is serious love, which will all harms appall,</br>Neglect whereof by many is deplor'd,</br>Ay me!  that herbs for love no cure afford!</br>Now for the fault wherof I am accus'd,</br>O blame me not, for 'tis no fault I us'd;</br>For if affection spurs a man to love,</br>Tis that affection needs must make him move</br>His sute to us, and wee, when we affect,</br>And see the like from them, seem to neglect</br>Their scorned sute, but so our frowns appear,</br>Mixt with a faint desire, and carefull fear</br>It should displease them, that we may unite,</br>A carelesse love, with an intire delight.</br>Again, when men doe see a curious stone,</br>The onely hopes of their foundation,</br>How often doe they slight with scornfull eye,</br>Neglect, disgrace, dispraise, and spurn it by?</br>The more to move and stir up an excesse</br>Of disrespect, and make the value lesse.</br>Even so we handle men, who still endure</br>A thousands deaths, to train us to their lure,</br>And were we sure they could not us forsake,</br>Wee'd dally more, even more delight to make.</br>Even so as men are caught, even so are we,</br>When we affect those that our service flee;</br>What kind salutes, imbraces and constraints</br>Ought we to use?  lest our untun'd complaints</br>Unpitied die, and we with sorrows scope,</br>As free from pleasure die, as free from hope.</br>Thou art a stranger Phaon to this place,</br>But I have known thy name, and know thy race,</br>Eumenion stories do thy honor tel,</br>Istria Eumenion knew thy Parents well,</br>Whose Fathers head upheld the weighty Crown</br>Of Illyris, which none could trample down,</br>Though many envi'd, free from harm he laid</br>His bones to rest, with whom the Crown decay'd.</br>Now fate to shew a modell of her power,</br>On thy Illyricum began to lower;</br>Thy Houshold Gods, acquainted with the cryes</br>Of thy decaying subjects, cast their eyes</br>This way, and that, twas yours O Gods to bid</br>Deniall to sedition that was hid</br>In Catelinian brests, and to surcease</br>The period of your domestick ease.</br>In this uprore (what fruits seditions bring</br>May well be guest, for every one was King)</br>The better sort prepar'd for thee and thine</br>A waftage over the beloved Rhyne</br>To Lesbos this; thou hadst not long bin here,</br>But private envy did thy walls uprear,</br>And did beguile to all posterity</br>Thee of thy glory, and the Crown of thee.</br>These things thy houshold Gods (to Lesbos brought)</br>Foreseeing good, have for thy own good wrought,</br>That thou maist gain a greater Crown than that</br>Illyrius had, and be more honor'd at</br>Those Festivalls, when yearly thou partak'st</br>Of Triumphs, which to Chimney Gods thou mak'st.</br>This was a work divine, and happy too,</br>(If any happiness from grief ensue)</br>That thou wast here conceal'd, for many vow'd,</br>And thundred forth the fame thereof aloud,</br>Of thy ensuing death, while thou wast still</br>In pupill age, and knew'st, nor did'st no ill,</br>But 'twas the Providence of you that dwell</br>In lofty Heav'ns (ye Powers) and to expell</br>All harm from him who must your Lawes maintain,</br>That when his perfect strength he doth obtain,</br>He may reward their deeds that envy bred,</br>And maugre those that to rebellion led.</br>Here wast thou brought, here hast thou daily staid,</br>And (while thy better subjects sought thee) plaid</br>Beguiling time away; perhaps you'd know,</br>What mov'd the powers to permit thee so</br>Untimely ruine, know they did anoint</br>Thee King of famous Lesbos, and appoint</br>This means alone to make their power approv'd,</br>And bring thee here of me to be belovd.</br>To this faint speech he intermission made</br>With heavy sighs, and then (fair Lady) said,</br>The Heav'ns have rob'd me of succeeding bliss,</br>And hid me from those means to grant you this</br>I most desire, behold my love I dye,</br>My troubled soule methinks doth seem to flye</br>Through silent Caves and Fields, two pleasant gates</br>Ope wide to take me in, wherein there waits</br>A Crown of gold, neither by arm or hand</br>Supported, but of its free power doth stand,</br>Now sits upon my head, these things I see,</br>And yet I live, can this a vision be?</br>About to stir, O stir me not he cries,</br>My feet stick fast, Sappho farewell, and dyes.</br>While yet he speaks, my Parents wayward fate,</br>Must be accompanied with the date</br>Of my despised life, a fearfull rind</br>Of Citron trembling redd, doth creeping bind</br>His not half closed speech, his curled hair,</br>Which gallants of his time did use to wear</br>Of an indifferent length, now upward heaves,</br>Towards the skyes their gold refulgent leaves.</br>Sappho at this exclaims, laments, invokes</br>No Power nor God, but seeks by hasty strokes,</br>As a fit sacrifice unto her friend,</br>From her beloved brest her soul to send.</br>Awhile she silent stood, belike to think,</br>Which was the safest way for her to drink</br>Of the same cup her Phaon did, at last</br>(As evill thoughts will quickly to one haste)</br>She saw the Spring that ran along the Grove,</br>'Tis you fair streams must send me to my Love.</br>Behold, dear Love, with what impatient heat,</br>My soul aspires to mount to that blest seat,</br>Where thou blest sit'st, stretch out thy sacred hand,</br>And with safe conduct draw me to that land,</br>That we may taste the joyes the vallie yeelds;</br>And hand in hand may walk th' Elisian fields.</br>This said, she turns her face unto the Tree,</br>And kissing it, said, if thou still can'st see,</br>Behold how irksome I enjoy that breath,</br>Which still detains my meeting thee in death:</br>With that she saw his sword, which she did take,</br>And having kiss'd it for the owners sake,</br>Salutes her brest with many weeping wounds,</br>Then casts her self into the Spring, and drown'ds.

There is a Hill in Paphlagonia, nam'd</br>Cytorus, whither this mischance was fam'd;</br>My self was present there when many rude,</br>And base untutur'd peasants did intrude</br>Into our games, they were, as since I heard</br>Those base insulting Traitors, that debarr'd</br>Wendenlands Crown from righteous Phaon's browe;</br>These (cause the Gods had quit them of the vowes</br>They made to work his death) with open cries,</br>Proclam'd their thanks, and sent them to the skies.</br>But Venus, who in constant love delights,</br>And ev'ry perfect amity requites,</br>Exil'd their joy, each one perceives their arms</br>To branches grow, each one partakes the harms</br>Of their deserts, a tree there is which bears</br>His summer hue, and it in winter wears,</br>To this she turns them, that continuall green</br>Might manifest their never pard'ned sinne.</br>This done I saw a Knight of courage bold,</br>Cloth'd all in argent armor, strip'd with gold,</br>Who vow'd, the death of one of us should pay</br>For her mishap, to crown the heavy day</br>With Anadems from his victorious hand,</br>I too too over forward, did demand</br>What was the cause; discourteous Knight he said,</br>Dost not repent thee that thou hast betraid</br>That honor'd Lady?  while I ignorant</br>Of what he meant, he said tis not the want</br>Of Launce, shall keep thee safe, till I have shown</br>Thy just revenge; so threw away his own.</br>But with his sword he taught me what to doe,</br>And I my self had sword and armor too</br>Ready to answer him; the fight was long,</br>And had been longer too, till I too strong,</br>With an unlucky blow, O wer't ungiven,</br>Betraid his life, and sent his soul to Heaven:</br>Twas Alphitheon, who of long had lov'd</br>Sappho, now dead, whose sute I oft had mov'd</br>In his behalf, now hearing of her fate,</br>Either increast in him suspitious hate</br>T'wards me; or furious else did frantick strike,</br>Amaz'd, unkind to every one alike;</br>Dying he knew me, and bewaild his losse,</br>My friend Arcadius said he, the crosse</br>Of this my present state, ought not to be</br>A blot to stain our former amitie</br>I die, let my remembrance have a place</br>In thy just heart, it shall be no disgrace.</br>Though envy stole my sense, O 'tis no blot,</br>No fault at all was mine; I knew thee not</br>When here I met thee first; My dearest friend;</br>I die, love the remembrance of my end.</br>So said, he went away, while I distraught</br>For grief of this inhumane wicked fault,</br>Vow'd never more to move a Ladies heart</br>Nor for my self, nor for anothers part.

Arcadius ceast, and Sepha's turn was now.</br>Who said (belov'd and worthy Knight) that vow</br>You eas'ly may infringe, and yet be blest.</br>A rash conceit was never held the best.</br>You say it may be, and it shall be so.</br>Arcadius said, chiefly for that I know</br>When virtue, beauty, and intire delight,</br>Our nere dissolv'd affection doe unite</br>The fault appears the less the glorious eyes</br>Of the All-seeing power do despise</br>Continuall grief, and Jove himself erst while</br>Carousing bouls of wine is seen to smile.</br>Fair Lady know, as yet to me unknown,</br>Your beauty and your virtues have oreflown</br>My willing yeelding sense, a secret fire,</br>Continually increasing through desire</br>To honor your admired parts, doth move,</br>By nought to be extinguisht but your love.</br>Love is a thing full of suspitious care,</br>By every churlish winde blown to dispair.</br>Silent Canius dy'd for love, not known</br>To her, who did his pure affection own.</br>I therefore ope my heart before your eyes,</br>Not doubting but you'r kinde as well as wise;</br>Not doubting but you'r wise as well as kinde.</br>Fair Sepha said, your worth I know may find</br>Far better Ladies, that may more content</br>Your love than I, and then you will repent</br>You of your deed, which still will you molest,</br>A rash conceit was never held the best.</br>Though all the beauties in the world were one,</br>Said he, and I by right might seize upon</br>The same, yet would I for thy vertues sake,</br>Aspire no better fortune, than to make</br>Thee my beloved wife, where ere thou art,</br>What ere thou dost, the Graces grace impart</br>To thy sweet self; this hair, this lovely hair,</br>If loose, as thou dost often use to wear,</br>Ostends thy freer beauty, or if knit,</br>It shews rare wisdome is inclos'd in it.</br>In fine they are the chains that link desire</br>In ev'ry brest, and kindle Cupids fire,</br>For which soever way thou dost them wear,</br>They fetch thee honour, and thy honour bear.</br>To me she said you please to speak the best,</br>O thought you of me so I should be blest,</br>Not that my fond conceit desires to bee</br>Linkt with each pleasing object that I see,</br>But of a long retain'd affection, I</br>Desire the bonds of perfect amity;</br>And since you please to honor me so well</br>With common friendship, that in all should dwell,</br>Tell me the name of that thrice blessed place</br>Injoyes your presence, and from what blest race</br>You draw your line; me Arathea claims</br>Said he, my much unhappy Parents names,</br>Were Capaneus, and Evadne, they</br>Of good report and noble progeny,</br>My Father, led by just revenge, was chief</br>Of those that wrought distressed Thebes grief,</br>Who having wed my Mother then but young</br>And of a pleasant face, whose Parents sprung</br>From Juno's brests, unto those wars was call'd;</br>Where after many skirmishes befall'd</br>To him this sad mishap, when various fights</br>Had clos'd up many with eternall nights,</br>He furious, and impatient of delay,</br>Resolv'd a quick dispatch, and with that day</br>To end the wars, a Ladder he devises,</br>Of cords compos'd, by which he enterprizes</br>Apparent means to scale the walls, but lo,</br>About to clime, some wicked hand doth throw</br>A stone upon him; yet i'l clime he said;</br>But while his soldiers came unto his aid,</br>For all their hopes upon his worth reli'd,</br>He gave directions for the wars and dy'd.</br>My Mother too too heavy for his harm,</br>Did help his wounded body to unarm,</br>When all his friends to honor him the more,</br>Were present, and his ruine did deplore.</br>But while the fire consumes with greedy flame</br>His flesh, my Mother runs into the same;</br>To shew when virtue shrines an upright heart,</br>Death never can united honor part.</br>In this Campania where my Castle stands,</br>I was instructed by the carefull hands</br>Of Callias, till understanding bad</br>Revenge be done for wrongs my Parents had.</br>I mov'd the wars afresh, what means I made,</br>With all-perswading reasons to perswade</br>The soldiers aid, is this

O You, said I, belov'd for upright wayes,</br>And fear'd of all for valour that obeys</br>Your conqu'ring arms!  I purpose not to add</br>Words to your virtues, nor my speech to cladd</br>With flattring robes, my just revenge shall cause</br>A triumph for that never scorn'd applause</br>Of your victorious fame, which daily mov'd</br>Towards your names, O you so well belov'd!</br>Your noble friend my Father, to whose shrine</br>You pay your yearly tears, is now divine,</br>He sorry for that harm which would betide</br>Your never conquered arms in that he dy'd,</br>Dy'd loth to leave you, now there is a time,</br>To heap revenge against them for that crime</br>Those Coward traytors acted, when they slew</br>Your noble friend my Father; let us view</br>The cause that moves us to display our war,</br>O is't not meritorious, and far</br>Beyond the price of their despised blood?</br>Your wisdome knowes your losse, our cause is good;</br>Too good alas for them, I know your love</br>Still, still, remains alive, which makes me move</br>Those valiant hearts which alwayes you injoy'd,</br>To seek revenge 'gainst those that have destroyd</br>Your noble friend my Father:  This, O this</br>Makes me require your help, nor greater bliss</br>Can to your dying tombes more honour gather,</br>Than to revenge your noble friend my Father.</br>O you so well belov'd, I need not show</br>The slothfull Thebans fearfulness, you know</br>The manner, and the matter of their war,</br>How through disorder, and discord they jar</br>Amongst themselves, your swords their Towers shake</br>At the remembrance of your names they quake.</br>When in the skirmage you your valour send,</br>To court their necks, and shew their lives their end,</br>Bethink you for whose sake you fight, and let</br>His wonted valor and remembrance whet</br>Your all-commanding swords, what greater gain</br>Than their subjection can you obtain?</br>Honor from thence will spring, their wealth and glories</br>By you enjoy'd, will fill your famous stories</br>With never-dying fame, and for your merit,</br>Your Sons shall everlasting praise inherit.</br>We for revenge, renown, and amity,</br>Our wars display, they but for liberty;</br>When we have girt their City with the choice</br>Of Martiall men, then shall we hear their voice</br>Come creeping to us, but our ears are stopt</br>From Traytors mouths, till we have overtopt</br>(For justice sake, on which we have reli'd)</br>Their weighty sins, and high aspiring pride.</br>O you belov'd of all, tis not a cause</br>Of little worth, nor only for applause</br>I move you to this War, survey your hearts,</br>There see his tomb, his wounds, and his deserts</br>Ever to be admir'd, your noble freind</br>My Father, whose too too unhappy end</br>Requires their blood desires no greater bliss,</br>Than to present his joyfull soul with this.</br>These and such words I us'd, with me they swore</br>To fetch the glory which the Thebans wore,</br>And plac't upon my Fathers tombe, to crown</br>Him with Heroick conquests, and renown.</br>With me they went, with me they overcame</br>The Thebans pride, and brought with them their fame.</br>Detain'd at wars, I saw you not, till late</br>Returning home, my ever happy fate</br>Blest me to hear your voice; My nimble Steed</br>To gratulate my labour with the deed,</br>So well belov'd (as if he knew my mind)</br>Lost me, that you fair Lady might me find.</br>At this she smiles, while his lov'd tale goes on;</br>Now since it is your chance to light upon</br>What was ordain'd your own, debar me not</br>That service from, which is my own by lot.</br>While I infolded in your love declare</br>Those sweet contents in Venus pleasures are.</br>For who with more delight can live?  What are</br>Those joyes that may with these delights compare?</br>She blusht and said, for e're she spake she blusht,</br>Then from her sweet, but angry lips there rusht</br>This angry speech, (beloved Sir) I owe</br>More inward zeal than yet I will bestow</br>On your lascivious love, and being near</br>Her Talmos, flung away, and would not hear</br>His quick-prepar'd excuse, who over-waid</br>With death-tormenting grief, look'd up and said,</br>Shall these contempts ore-rule thy virtuous will?</br>O Sepha, knowest thou whom thy scorns do kill?</br>Well she goes on, nor looks behind to see</br>The fruits of her disdain, his Amitie,</br>But hasted home, by fond suspition led;</br>(So Arethusa from Alphaeus fled)</br>Till to her chamber come, she unawares,</br>(Beginning now to be perplext with cares)</br>Look'd from a window, from a window spy'd</br>Her fair Arcadius dead, even then she cry'd.</br>Her nimble feet had not such power to bear</br>Her half so fast away, as now her fear</br>Returns her to him, ready to complain</br>Upon her fate, her tender eyes doe strain</br>Balm to bedew his cheeks, till a sweet kiss,</br>(It seems beloved better than that blisse</br>The Heav'ns bestow'd) recall'd his sleepy eyes,</br>Who opening first, straight shut again and lyes</br>Clos'd in her arms, as if nought more could grace him,</br>With greater joyes, than when her arms imbrace him:</br>At length remembrance (usherd by a grone)</br>Proclaim'd his life; and am I left alone?</br>He said, then op't his eyes, whose fixed sight</br>Not yet from deaths imbracings free, did light</br>Upon her face, about his voice to raise,</br>Soft kisses stop his speech, those past he sayes,

Yee Gods, whose too too hasty shafts have strook</br>Beguiling joyes into my eyes, and took</br>My heavy soule from that thrice blessed place</br>Where Sepha dwells, who must Elisium grace,</br>What yeelds this Heav'n?  O would I still might live,</br>Her presence yeelds more joyes than Heav'n can give;</br>Invest me with all pleasures that you please</br>In Heav'n to have, with Canticles of ease</br>That follow pious soules, they nought will yield</br>To me but grief; while o're th' Elisian field,</br>And gloomy shades, continuall steps I take</br>For her safe waftage or'e the Stygian lake.</br>These words he spake, taking her face for Heaven,</br>(In whom the Powers, all powerfull grace had given)</br>Where still he thought he was, while Sepha griev'd,</br>With cordiall water from her eyes, reviv'd</br>His not yet living sense, with greedy eyes</br>He views her face, who with this speech replyes.</br>To me 'tis strange, that you (within whose brest</br>Such rare undaunted strength and wit doth rest)</br>Through foolish grief should yeeld your sacred soul</br>To Charons boat, who shall your death condole</br>So slightly caus'd?  shall I?  beleeve me no,</br>I'le rather seek some noble means to show</br>How much you strive with faint tormenting mind</br>To raise that heart wherein you lie inshrind.</br>Should men dispair for once or twice refusall,</br>Few men would speed, for to our Sex tis usual;</br>And often, words outstep the carelesse lip,</br>Which past, repent that e're they let them slip.</br>Now let this message in thy bosome light</br>Arcadius, thou art the sole delight</br>Of this my wretched life, for thee I live,</br>To live with thee, to thee my love I give.</br>Preserve it then so worthy to be lov'd,</br>That of thee alwayes I may be belov'd:</br>Let no lascivious thought pollute the same,</br>Which may increase a scandall to my name,</br>But with unstain'd desires let me be led</br>By Hymens rites unspotted to thy bed.</br>Have you not heard young lambs with wailing cries</br>Lament their dams departure?  who still lies</br>Under the sheerers hands?  with discontent</br>Thinking them dead, their sudden death lament?</br>While they to hinder the bemoning notes</br>Get up, and pay their ransome with their coats.</br>Even so Arcadius with attentive care,</br>Observ'd each word her heav'nly lips did spare,</br>Still fearing lest some various conclusion,</br>Should draw his life to sable nights confusion.</br>But when he heard the full, Ladies I know</br>You can conceive what streams of joy did flow</br>In his still honor'd brest, he nimbly rose,</br>Conjur'd the Air to keep her message close</br>From babling Ecchoes, to her self he vows</br>An amrous kiss, and she his kiss allows.</br>He crav'd remission for his faulty words,</br>Now askt, and straight remission she affords,</br>And binds him to the limits of unstain'd</br>Desire, and with her golden tresses chain'd</br>His heart from all deceit, with such pure grace,</br>As ought in ev'ry lover to have place;</br>To Talmos she (proud of her prize) him ledd,</br>(For know fair Sepha's parents both were dead)</br>Where entertain'd with many royall sips</br>He drunk full boules of Nectar from her lips.</br>Time hasty to produce the marriage day</br>Of these impatient lovers, hy'd his way;</br>And Sepha after many sweet imbraces,</br>Fraught with conceit, and stuft with interlaces</br>Of their ensuing pleasure, did permit</br>Arcadius departure, who unfit</br>For any service, but the winged God,</br>To Arathea went, and as he rode,</br>Oft blam'd orehasty time their joy t' undo,</br>But prais'd him for the sports that should ensue.</br>Now was it when the fraction of the day</br>From sable night had made Aurora way,</br>When I [Author's note: Epimenides], ambiguous of suceeding fate,</br>Forsook my native countrey for the hate</br>'Gainst me conceiv'd, me Minos Country bred</br>Whose hundred Cities with amazement led</br>Each eye to view their pride; My Father old,</br>And I a pretty stripling, did uphold</br>The staffe of his declining age, with care</br>I cherisht him, and did the burthen bear</br>Of his domestick ployments, now it was,</br>(When all his businesse through my hands did pass)</br>That once he sent me to attend the sheep,</br>Where Woods sweet chanters summon'd me to sleep:</br>Within a Cave of Parian stone compos'd,</br>I laid me down, I laid me down, and clos'd</br>My duskish eyes, sure some inchantments kept</br>The same with Magick spells, for there I slept</br>Whole seventeen years away; awak'd at last,</br>I got me up, and to my home did haste,</br>Not knowing so much time away was fled,</br>I call'd my friends, but lo, my friends were dead.</br>This known I left Minoia, and spent</br>My dayes in Rome, not caring where I went,</br>Nor what I did; nor there I long remaind,</br>Cause more mishap was to my life ordain'd:</br>Mugiona stands pointing to a way</br>Call'd Appia, through which my journey lay;</br>Nor many dayes were spent before I came</br>Unto that Town which Sora hath to name;</br>And there a while I staid, a while I strove</br>To kill those griefs, which never ceas'd to move</br>A desp'rate end, for that unwisht mischance</br>Still gnawing on my soul, about t' advance</br>My sword towards my end, O stay a while</br>A voice bespake, let not thy wrath beguile</br>Thee of succeding joyes; amaz'd I stood,</br>Not knowing why to save, or spill my blood.</br>My eyes could shew me nothing, but my ears</br>Granted a convoy for the sob'd-forth tears</br>Of a distressed Lady, what mishap</br>Hath Fortune more, said she, than to intrap</br>Our joyes, and cut them off?  the voice did guide</br>Me to a little grove, wherein I spi'd</br>A wretched Lady with torn hair discover,</br>(O're the dead corps of her beloved lover)</br>Th' irreparable loss, and hatefull breath,</br>She did sustain through his untimely death.</br>Agast she trembled, and with liquid eyes,</br>Sent with her lovers soul into the skyes,</br>Prayes that her end may with his end appear,</br>Or here to have him, or to have him there.</br>A while I stood, either with fear o'regon,</br>Or else with grief not able to go on,</br>Till she with sword tug'd from his wounded brest,</br>Made passage for her souls eternall rest.</br>I hi'd me to her, but my steps were lost,</br>The wound was given; saith she, since we are crost</br>Of Terrene pleasures, and those joyes do miss,</br>Our soules shall wed in Heav'ns eternall bliss.</br>I striv'd to stop her blood, but she deny'd</br>That any favour should to her betide,</br>Since she was cross'd in all designes, and said,</br>If the entreaties of a dying maid,</br>Sir Knight may move you, grant this last request,</br>With your own sword give period to the rest</br>Of him who did my Delithason slay,</br>O're yon ambitious hill he took his way.</br>I vow'd their deaths revenge, withall desir'd,</br>Since she would die, before her life expir'd</br>Its glorious date, t' acquaint my pitying ears</br>With her sad story, while whole shours of tears</br>Imbalm the body dead; alas said she,</br>You cause me to renew the grief must be</br>My pasport to his soul, then faintly rais'd</br>Her weary head:  For ever be ye prais'd</br>(Ye Powrs) that grant me liberty t' unfold</br>Our Tragick ends, and then this story told.

THE STORY OF DELITHASON AND VERISTA.</br>Not far remote there are four little lands,</br>Rul'd by that God, who girts them with his hands;</br>Statinae call'd, in these my Father dwelt,</br>Whose alwayes scraping, but nere fill'd hand felt</br>A mean of Fortunes good, (whether by Fate,</br>Or fore-ordained to expire the date</br>Of my distressed life) to me t's unknown,</br>But wealth (with which those Isles have ever flown)</br>Heap'd to his hands a still encreasing croud</br>Of gilded pills, those riches made him proud.</br>Amongst the other fortunes that he had,</br>(O whether shall I term it good or bad)</br>The Heav'ns assign'd him me, Verista nam'd,</br>Who yet but young, a false report had fam'd</br>Rare beauty of me; this, O this declar'd,</br>Draw'd many Princes that the same had heard,</br>To try the judgment of their eyes, which fame</br>By some confirm'd, this Delithason came,</br>(Not like a Prince, as like a Prince he might,</br>Because he was a Prince) but like a Knight</br>With Sword and Lance, but first I'd have you know</br>My Father amongst many had a foe</br>Of Gyants race, whose heart enur'd to wrong,</br>To rapes, and base oppressions had long</br>Appli'd his strength, and now to torture more</br>My Fathers brest that life might give him o're,</br>This quarrell pick'd, he came and did demand</br>Me for his wife, and cause we did withstand</br>His wish, with kindled rage from Pluto's Cell,</br>He shakes his dangling locks, and down to Hell</br>A journey takes, Erinnis he implor'd,</br>And all the Furies which he there ador'd,</br>T' assist his new found plot, nor yet in vain</br>They adde their help, with fire they rent in twain</br>A Town my Father own'd, the dwellers there</br>Affraid of death, t' abolish quite their fear,</br>Plastred the walls with brains, their limbs bestrew'd</br>The blushing streets with streams of blood bedew'd.</br>To this he adds a mischief worse, and throwes</br>Blasphemous oaths, on which he did repose,</br>Up to Saturnus son, the sacred stones,</br>On which the people laid oblations,</br>He hurls about the Temple, from the posts</br>The gold he tears, and in his mischief boasts.</br>By this my brother, guided by the cryes</br>Of conquer'd sounds, came staring in, and spies</br>The honors of Celestiall Gods defac't,</br>A sling he had, and from that sling did cast</br>The over hastie stone, and though he well</br>Could use his sling, yet did his art excell</br>In managing his sword, now heav'd aloft,</br>Threatning the Gyants death, said he, how oft</br>Shall I be vext with too too partiall eye</br>Of thy outrage?  perish with this and dye.</br>His speech scarce clos'd, Marfilos smear'd with blood,</br>A colebrand snatcht which by the altar stood,</br>And sends it to my brother, 'twas espy'd</br>By Delithason this, about to slide</br>Along the Air, with Lance he stopt his hand,</br>And sent his soul to that infernall land,</br>Where ghosts with hideous cries indure the right</br>Of their deserts, cloath'd in Eternall night.</br>Thus Delithason by the clamors call'd,</br>And by the Gyants death the same appall'd;</br>Restor'd to every man his own, the rather</br>To get (the seldom got) love of my Father;</br>Who nothing thankfull for so great a favour,</br>Gave thanks indeed; but with so rude behaviour,</br>That nought was heard but sighs and pittious moan,</br>How to regain the harm to him was done.</br>I must said he, omit the charge I us'd</br>In keeping house, by which I have abus'd</br>My quite-consumed stock; I must omit</br>The courteous entertainment that is fit</br>For worthy guess, and so to end the strife</br>Of sleeping age, with a retired life;</br>To this the Prince, (whose ever piety</br>Still lent discourteous acts a noble eye)</br>Sayes, aged Father your declining head</br>Should scorn to be to base Rebellion led</br>Against the Lawes of Hospitality;</br>Decrepit age should on the good rely</br>Which she hath done, not on her present wealth,</br>The souls decay, opposer to her health.</br>O whither shall I turn?  assist me now</br>Ye ever helping Powers, let not a vow</br>So firmly made before your holy fires,</br>So eas'ly be infring'd; but who aspires</br>To mount the chariot where the glorious Sun</br>The orb surveys, with pride shall be undon.</br>And shall I silent dye?  Shall this exile</br>From hopes, the pure bond of my love defile?</br>Shall my desir'd desires with horrid sound</br>Of a faint heart increase m' increasing wound?</br>No, Love must fear no harm, he is not fit</br>T' enjoy Loves fruits, that hath not firmly knit</br>A resolution to his hopes, and ty'd</br>Himself, though oft, yet ne're to be deny'd.</br>Father, the wings of ever warbling fame</br>Exempt alone, chatter'd the glorious name</br>Of your Verista's beauty, 'twas my chance,</br>When ev'ry Eccho did the same advance</br>In lofty tunes, to hap into your fight,</br>And being greedy of so great a sight,</br>Gave period to all hopes of other beauty,</br>And did besiege her heart, 'tis now her duty</br>My pleasure to obey, for Hymens lights</br>Have linkt our hearts, with honour of those rites</br>To Lovers due, be willing then to it</br>Since Fate hath stop'd all means the bond t' unknit.</br>But if you will not, if you will persever</br>In hatred to those Princes, that endeavor</br>To bless their happy lives in blessing her;</br>I say again, if still you will prefer</br>Your will before all reason without reason,</br>As hitherto you have don, there's a Season</br>Call'd quiv'ring winter, with his milky bride,</br>Will freez your honor, and abate your pride.</br>Imperiall I, in fair Zephire sit,</br>Whom wealthy Caria bounds, and brags of it,</br>There flowes that paltry gold so much I hate,</br>I think the more t' impare my quiet state.</br>Luxurious brat, and enemy to wealth,</br>My Father said, th' hast got the Crown by stealth,</br>With it Verista's love, and do'st thou think</br>My Daughter shall of that stolne honour drink?</br>First let my hands imbrew their wrinkled skin</br>In her false breast, first let the spoyle begin</br>Upon my off-spring, can thy boasts assure her?</br>Or the bare title of a Crown procure her</br>Contented wealth?  Say, can so great a name,</br>As Queen of Caria wipe away the blame</br>Of disobedience?  or release the oath</br>Of duty?  or of zealous care?  or both?</br>Which she (when subject to my tender rodds,)</br>Made in the presence of the better Gods?</br>Here Delithason staid his speech, too late,</br>He said, you vent your nere consumed hate.</br>The Gods observe your deeds, and though a while</br>They slack their vengance, tis but to beguile</br>The Offenders with false hopes; so said, he turn'd</br>His head about, and on the Altar burn'd</br>Prepared Incense, strait the Altar brake</br>In twain, and after a fierce Thunder-clap,</br>Sweet Musick breath'd, in which a Chanter cry'd,</br>Thy time's expir'd, and thou art deifi'd.</br>Amaz'd the people stand, nor yet to whom,</br>They can conceive this prophecie should come;</br>Not I alas, no, nor my feeble heart,</br>Fore-thought of this, of this untimely dart,</br>For so it hapt, Marfilos had a son,</br>(From a corrupted spring ill waters run)</br>Who (wicked) at his fathers death repining,</br>Just as the Sun was to his bed declining,</br>Observ'd when I and Delithason hy'd</br>T'wards his Zephire, (for being denide</br>My Fathers Blessing, privily we got</br>Away, when careless he observed not)</br>And passing through this wood this Bloody wood</br>(A closet for those that delight in Blood)</br>The Gyants son a twinded Javelin cast,</br>And made this wound you see, that don, in haste</br>Knowing his dart this spotless heart had sped,</br>Unto his home, his fathers den he fled:</br>About to tell the rest she stopt, and dy'd,</br>When I by vertue of my promise ty'd,</br>After I had repos'd them in one Urne,</br>Towards Statinae did my voyage turne,</br>And (lest too long I should delay the joy,</br>Hasty Arcadius wishes to enjoy)</br>Stuft up with Ire, I did not long pursue</br>His steps, before at him I had a view.</br>Ho!  villaine stay, I cry'd, receive the meed,</br>The Gods alot thee for thy wicked deed,</br>Stay Murtherer, thy haste shall not prefer,</br>Injustice before right, stay Murtherer,</br>While yet I spake, my Lance his shoulders caught,</br>My Sword beguild him of his head, and taught</br>This lesson to the world, th' allseeing Eye,</br>Lets not apparent wrongs unpunish'd dye.</br>My vow dissolv'd, I bent my course again</br>Towards Abella, whose high walls disdain</br>A rivall in their prid, there is a way</br>That leads thereto, by which a medow lay,</br>In it I saw a Knight of Silver hew,</br>With sword, hold a stout Combat against two</br>Of fiery looks, I hy'd me to the fight,</br>Either by force or Treaty to unite</br>Their various minds, but what can words prevail,</br>Where bloody resolutions do assail</br>A spotless minde?  no time they would admit,</br>Through hasty fight, t' inquire the cause of it.</br>A while I view'd the Combate, till the Knight</br>In silver armor on the neck did light</br>Of one of th' adverse side, who unacquainted</br>With such rough complements, fell down and fainted.</br>So done, he said, by all the Powers that dwell</br>In lofty thrones, thy valour doth excell</br>Thy neighb'ring Princes, but thy unjust cause,</br>Repugne against the splendor, and the lawes</br>Of Martiall discipline, content thee then</br>With this, thou art the happiest of men</br>In that th' hast scap'd revenge to traytors due,</br>Do other matters cause thee to pursue</br>This spite, besides thy false suspect?  or can</br>Thy ever-stain'd affection (which began</br>And ends with lust, not love) enchant thy sense</br>So far with stupid blindnesse to commence</br>Hatred for this?  withdraw thy self and yeeld</br>To me thy life, thy weapon, and the field.</br>So shall my arms with amity imbrace</br>Thy neck; where else 'twill shew thee thy disgrace.</br>No sooner said, but we might hear the sounde</br>Of trampling horses beat the tender ground</br>For swifter speed now to us seen, and now</br>Dismount their Steeds, and to the adverse bow,</br>Pardon said they (great Prince) that our neglect</br>Infring'd the Laws of our indeer'd respect.</br>But when they saw his armor stain'd, and view'd,</br>His dead companion with blood imbru'd,</br>They re-amount the nimble Steeds they rid,</br>(For Marble look'd not paler than they did)</br>And to the silver Knight their anger bent,</br>Who with excess of bleeding almost spent,</br>Held up his hand to me, to me he said,</br>(For they were three) see how I am betraid</br>With these unequall odds, no more you need</br>To move me up I said, fear not, proceed</br>With your own hands to lacerate in twain</br>Their conscious hearts, to me your prayers are vain.</br>I am too weak to shelter you from harms,</br>Though arm'd, yet I'm unskill'd to use my arms,</br>But what I am I'm yours, with that our swords</br>We drew, and blows supply'd the want of words.</br>While he (most noble and most valiant Knight)</br>Each blow he took, each blow he did requite</br>With treble use, awhile they hold us play,</br>Till overcome, their lives did end our fray.</br>This done, and all things hist, I thought it good</br>To stop the conduits of his flowing blood,</br>When mounted on our Steeds, with gentle gate</br>Riding towarde his home, he did relate</br>The tragick story thus; I am said he</br>Arcadius, and yonder Towr you see</br>Is mine, this Prince whom now we slew,</br>Hearing what pure unstain'd affection grew</br>'Tween me, and one nam'd Sepha in her heart,</br>He came, and did prescribe a double part:</br>On this our quarrell grew, and what success</br>In it he had, your valour will express.</br>Not I, said I, 'twas you your conquering hand,</br>Your cause, your sword, your strength that did withstand</br>Their greedy hopes, the Gods do close their eyes</br>From impious vassals, and exclude their cryes.</br>And since you please t' intitle me your friend,</br>O let my willing service you attend,</br>And what you think will magnifie your name,</br>Withall conceive me ready for the same.</br>'Twas Summer then, and having cur'd his wounds</br>Call'd out by th' noise of his pursuing hounds,</br>We gallopp'd o're the plains, now by a Wood</br>Our way we took, where purple statues stood,</br>O blesse me here he cry'd, and softly said,</br>Inshrind in these four pleasant Nymphs are laid.</br>Then by a Tower, in this said he remains</br>The fairest flower, the pride of all the plains,</br>'Tis Sepha's house, the Goddess of my heart,</br>In whose fair cheeks, Love with his golden dart</br>Sits sporting, dasht with a Vermilion dye,</br>Th' are like the blush came from Endymions eye,</br>When twin-born Cynthia to suffice her will,</br>Had courted him on sleepy Latmos hill.</br>No sooner said, but Sepha said 'tis true,</br>If lik'd of you, for Sepha lives by you,</br>And spying me she blush'd, lovers doe so,</br>For conscious minds appear by th' outward shew;</br>All salutations past, she led us in,</br>Where first our root of ruine did begin:</br>For such firm bonds of constant amity,</br>Had link'd Arcadius loyall heart to me,</br>(Which by our outward actions was not hid,</br>For never two lov'd better than we did)</br>That she perceiving how he stood inclin'd,</br>The more to please and gratulate his mind,</br>Us'd me with courteous terms, he discontent,</br>(Suspition is a tryall eminent</br>Of true affection) thought some new-born love</br>'Twards me increast, her tender heart did move</br>As Helen did to Paris, took occasion,</br>T' assist her loyall love with this perswasion;</br>For sitting in a pleasant bower which hung</br>With various flowres he took a Lute and sung.

See'st not my love with what a grace?</br>The Spring resembles thy sweet face?</br>Here let us sit, and in these bowers,</br>Receive the odors of the flowers,</br>For Flora by thy beauty wood,</br>conspires thy good.

See how she sends her fragrant sweet,</br>And doth this homage to thy feet,</br>Bending so low her stooping head,</br>To kiss the ground where thou dost tread,</br>And all her flowers proudly meet,</br>to kiss thy feet.

Then let us walk my dearest love,</br>And on this carpet strictly prove</br>Each others vow, from thy request</br>No other love invades my brest.</br>For how can I contemn that fire</br>which Gods admire?

To crop that Rose why dost thou seek,</br>When there's a purer in thy cheek?</br>Like Corall held in thy fair hands,</br>Or blood and milk that mingled stands;</br>To whom the Powers all grace have given.</br>a type of Heaven.

Yon Lillie stooping 'twards this place,</br>Is a pale shadow for thy face,</br>Under which veil doth seem to rush;</br>Modest Endymions ruddy blush.</br>A blush indeed, more pure and fair</br>than Lillies are.

Glance on those flowers thy radiant eyes,</br>Through which cleer beams they'l sympathize</br>Reflective love, to make them far</br>More glorious than th' Hesperian star,</br>For every swain amazed lies,</br>and gazing dies.

See how these silly flowers twine,</br>With sweet imbracings, and combine,</br>Striving with curious looms to set</br>Their pale and red into a net,</br>To shew how pure desire doth rest</br>for ever blest.
Why wilt thou then unconstant be?</br>T' infringe the lawes of amity?</br>And so much dis-respect my heart?</br>To derogate from what thou art?</br>When in harmonious love there is</br>Elisian bliss.

Sepha at this was pleas'd, displeas'd was he</br>To see her smile; leave off thy jealousie</br>Arcadius she said, I am possest</br>With that firm love, which nere shall leave my brest.</br>First shall the Sun forget his course to flie,</br>And Pindus hills shall soar about the skie.</br>First shall the Roman Eagles lose their wings,</br>And musick murmur musick without strings.</br>First shall the Sea-born Goddesse leave the fan</br>Of ardent love, and turn precisian:</br>And fearfull Hares pursue the thundring cry</br>Of Cretan Hounds, and Ovids mem'ry dy,</br>Er'e I, who to thee do my soul betroth,</br>Forsake my word, or falsify my oath.</br>So said, she hangs her lip, and lours her head,</br>(Lovers are oft asham'd of what they sed)</br>While he with hymns of joy the debt did pay</br>Of upright love, and nam'd the wedding day.</br>Which come, and all things ready, Sepha drest</br>Her hair, her coats were blew, upon her brest</br>She wore a Stone of curious art compos'd,</br>Wherein two naked lovers were inclos'd;</br>Both striving, till the maid who did resist,</br>Grew weak, and then he us'd her as he list.</br>Now Ladies, know; a Prince there was whom fame</br>Had taken captive with fair Sepha's name,</br>Who hearing of the wedding day, wherein</br>Their hands should be linkt, as their hearts had bin;</br>And hearing of the weakness of the guard,</br>That should conduct them to the Church, prepar'd</br>To rob us of her; as you pass the plain,</br>There is a prety hillock that would fain</br>Be call'd a hill, behind this hill they hide</br>Themselves, their weapons, and doe there reside.</br>Now we in whom no thought of treachery</br>Had told us of mishap, with jollity</br>Hy'd to the temple, there, O there the chance</br>Of base conspiring mischief did advance</br>It self, dejected us, a horrid voice</br>Of threatning people sent a hideous noise</br>Unto our ears, now to our eys their arms</br>With glittring shields foretell our following harms.</br>Unweapon'd we, for battels are refus'd</br>On wedding days, and other weapons us'd,</br>So that the easier they our necks did bend</br>Unto their yoke, now had they took my friend</br>The yong Arcadius and his lovely bride,</br>The onely prize they waited for, and hy'd</br>Them on their way, born by the heat of love</br>'Twards th' one, 'twards th' other hate their speed did move,</br>When I (O ne're till then unfortunate)</br>Saw Tyranny and malice at debate,</br>Who first should steal away the spotless life</br>Of my Arcadius, at last a knife,</br>His unstain'd bosome pierc'd, who dying cry'd,</br>Let Sepha live, and I am satisfied.</br>You ravishers said I of others blood,</br>By this discern if Traytors ends are good,</br>And with a sword snatch'd from anothers arm,</br>Cleft one, and said be sharer in his harm;</br>With that a second, and a third I slew,</br>And so a fourth, till such a tumult grew,</br>That after divers blows away they fled,</br>And left me, as they well might think for dead.</br>Mean while Campanian Sepha took her flight</br>Into a Wood, born there by horrid fright.</br>Where long she could not stay, by carefull heed</br>Drawn forth, to know how her known love did speed,</br>And now she finds, what nere she wisht to find,</br>With his dear bloud the blushing flowers lin'd;</br>She sayes not much, lest helplesse words should stay</br>Her soul too long, but kneeling down doth pray,</br>Then took the knife by his own blood made foul,</br>And falling down upon't advanc't her soul.</br>Awak'd from out my sound, I saw how Fate</br>Had plaid the wanton, and expir'd their date:</br>I took their bodies and them both did burn,</br>I put them both together in one Urn;</br>Strait both their ashes, Male and Female grew,</br>And from the same admired Phoenix flew;</br>From whence I Prophesie it shall revive</br>By death, for tis their fame shall keep't alive,</br>Which growing old towards the Sun shall flie,</br>And till the Heavens dissolve shall never dye.

Here Epimenides his story ceast,</br>And bending down his panting bosome dyes:</br>Whose death the Ladies former griefs increast,</br>They sent his Soule to Elizium with their cryes,</br>Upon whose shrine they wrot his death, to show</br>From Heaven he came, to Heaven he needs must go.</br>
